Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Studies in ecology, environmental and conservation biology in Ghana, West Africa
Award.AbstractNarration: An award has been made to Virginia Tech that will provide research training for 8 weeks for 6 students, during the summers of 2011- 2015. The award, which is also supported by the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering, supports the continuation of the international Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site program at the University of Cape Coast (UCC), Ghana that has taken place in the past 8 years. The program focuses on ecology, ethnobotany, biodiversity and conservation and environmental biology in the tropics. The students will work on defined research projects under the mentorship of Ghanaian scientists and faculty members. Students will be selected based on their academic record and motivation to attend graduate school. This program has two main research foci: i) bioprospecting for potentially useful plants and ii) ecological and biodiversity studies. Students will design experiments in collaboration with their mentors, collect and analyze their data, and present their results in Ghana. They will conduct full time research during the weekdays and attend seminars and group discussions during the evenings. Over the weekends, field trips will be made (such as to the Mole game reserve, the Kakum National forest, and the Kakum estuary) to provide the students with additional experience that will enhance their understanding of ecology and conservation. Upon their return to the US, students will make presentations at regional and national meetings. Participants will acquire skills in ethnobotany, tropical biology, aquaculture, ecology, entomology, taxonomy and analytical chemistry. They will be expected to publish their results in peer-reviewed journals. The ecological studies will yield new and valuable information on tropical species of insects and plants that may not have been described in the literature yet. Data gathered in the project will also contribute towards an inventory of potentially endangered species and conservation studies. Participants will have an invaluable cross-cultural experience. Students will be tracked through annual surveys and the program will be evaluated using various methods including the REU common assessment tool. More information is available at http://www.undergraduate.vt.edu/GhanaREU/ or by contacting the PI (Dr. Daniel Wubah at wubah@vt.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Judith Wubah at jawubah@vt.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the international Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site program at the University of Cape Coast (UCC), Ghana that focuses on ecology, ethnobotany, biodiversity and conservation and environmental biology in the tropics. The host institutions were Virginia Tech (2010-2013) and Washington and Lee University (2014-2015).  A total of twenty-eight students from US universities spent eight weeks at UCC during the summer working on defined research projects under the mentorship of Ghanaian scientists and faculty members. Students were selected based on their academic record, preparation and motivation to attend graduate school. Each year, at least 50% of the participants were from under-represented minority groups and/or first generation students. The home institution of the participants included Colby College, Colorado College, Cornell University, Frostburg University, Harvard University, Howard University, Illinois State University, Pomona College, Rice University, Towson University, Marshall University, Virginia Tech, University of the Atlantic, University of Delaware, Washington and Lee University, and Washington University. 

The program had two main research foci: i) bioprospecting for potentially useful plants and ii) ecological and biodiversity studies. Students designed experiments in collaboration with their faculty mentors, collected and analyzed their data, and presented their results in Ghana at the end of the program. They worked on their research projects from Monday through Friday. In addition to attending seminars presented in their host departments, students attended two weekly seminars: one focused on science in Africa and the other focused on Ghanaian culture. The topics varied from the use of music in Ghanaian culture, through major festivals in different tribes in Ghana to laser photonics in the treatment of diseases in Ghana. They also took part in weekly group discussions and field trips to cultural and scientific research sites during the weekend. During the weekends, they went on field trips to cultural and historical sites such as the Cape Coast Castle, Elmina Castle, Bonwire in the Ashanti Region and the Mole game reserve. Among the field sites that they visited were the Kakum National forest, rocky beaches of Elmina and the Kakum estuary. Upon their return to the US, students made presentations at regional and national meetings.

Participants acquired skills in ethnobotany, molecular biology techniques, tropical biology, aquaculture, ecology, entomology, taxonomy and analytical chemistry. The ecological studies yielded valuable information on tropical species of insects and plants that were not previously described in the literature. For example, new data wer collected on colony development by stingless bees and mosquito resistance to various insecticides. Data gathered in the project will also contribute towards an inventory of potentially endangered species and conservation studies. Participants had an invaluable cross-cultural experience.

Beyond the research experience, students developed professional relationships with their Ghanaian hosts and peer mentors. Such relationships have yielded positive outcomes such a participant from the 2012 group going back to Ghana for collect data for her master's research project and to help initiate a non-governmental organization. Another student went back to Ghana for a Fulbright fellowship after participating in the REU program.
